example: Seagoing vessels have been used for trade across oceans for thousands of years.
The aquarium will exhibit rare deep-sea creatures in its new underwater tunnel.
Mature salmon return to their birthplace to breed in freshwater streams.
Salmon migrate thousands of miles from the ocean to spawn in rivers.
Many sea creatures breed in shallow waters to protect their offspring.
Turtle eggs hatch on the beach, and the young make their way to the sea.
Fish dart through the coral reef to avoid predators in the ocean.
Frogs spawn in ponds, and their tadpoles develop in the freshwater.
Seabirds obtain food by diving into the ocean to catch fish.
Baboons live in social groups and forage for food during the day.
Sharks are apex predators that play a crucial role in marine ecosystems.
Birds emit loud calls to alert their flock about approaching predators.
Bees spread pollen from flower to flower, aiding in plant reproduction.
Baboons forage for fruits, leaves, and insects in their natural habitat.
Mother whales feed their calves with nutrient-rich milk for several months.
Monkeys groom each other to maintain social bonds and remove parasites.
Many bird species migrate south for the winter to find food.
Salmon start their lives in freshwater rivers before moving to the ocean.
Camouflage is a key survival strategy for many species in the wild.
Seals rest on beaches temporarily before returning to the ocean to feed.
The whale's stomach has a large capacity to hold tons of small fish and krill.
Animals have to make careful allocation of energy for foraging and reproduction.
Most sea creatures reproduce by laying eggs in the water.
Animals migrate to fulfill their survival needs, such as finding food and suitable habitats.
Pollution can disrupt the natural breeding cycles of marine species.
Each species has distinct coloring to adapt to its environment.
The frog's bright coloring warns predators of its toxicity.
Octopuses employ camouflage to blend in with their surroundings.
Eagles spot their prey from high in the sky before diving to catch it.
Bees collect pollen to feed their young and help plants reproduce.
Butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long tongues.
Many species of fish are threatened by overfishing and ocean pollution.
Baby sea turtles are vulnerable to predators when they hatch and head to the ocean.
Sharks are adapted to live in salt water but can't survive in freshwater.
Salmon return to freshwater to spawn when they reach a certain age.
Animals' behaviors are often driven by their survival needs, like finding food and shelter.
Birds migrate south in response to the changing seasons and food availability.
Monkeys engage in grooming to maintain social relationships within their group.
The seal attempts to catch fish by darting through the water quickly.
The chameleon's physical features allow it to change color and blend into its environment.
A turtle's shell is its primary defense mechanism against predators.
Bees transfer pollen between flowers as they collect nectar, aiding in plant growth.
Only a limited number of species can survive in the extreme conditions of the deep sea.
The islands in the archipelago are spread far apart, each with unique species.
When threatened, the school of fish spreads out to confuse predators.
Bears come out of hibernation to search for food in the spring.
Salmon take several years to grow to full size in the ocean before spawning.
When a predator approaches, the fish darts back down into safety among the coral.
Many sea creatures have adapted to survive in the deep, dark parts of the ocean.
